TITLE: Visualizing Basic Diátaxis Documentation Structure
DESCRIPTION: A text representation of a standard Diátaxis documentation structure with four main sections (Tutorial, How-to guides, Reference, Explanation) and their contents, showing the hierarchy with landing pages.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/complex-hierarchies.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
Home                      <- landing page
    Tutorial              <- landing page
        Part 1
        Part 2
        Part 3
    How-to guides         <- landing page
        Install
        Deploy
        Scale
    Reference             <- landing page
        Command-line tool
        Available endpoints
        API
    Explanation           <- landing page
        Best practice recommendations
        Security overview
        Performance
```

TITLE: RST Table Structure for Diátaxis Compass
DESCRIPTION: A reStructuredText table defining the relationships between content type, user needs, and documentation categories in the Diátaxis framework.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/start-here.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: restructuredtext
CODE:
```
.. list-table::
   :widths: 33 33 34
   :header-rows: 1
   :stub-columns: 0
   :class: wider

   * - If the content...
     - ...and serves the user's...
     - ...then it must belong to...
   * - informs action
     - acquisition of skill
     - a tutorial
   * - informs action
     - application of skill
     - a how-to guide
   * - informs cognition
     - application of skill
     - reference
   * - informs cognition
     - acquisition of skill
     - explanation
```

TITLE: Creating a Documentation Types Comparison Table in reStructuredText
DESCRIPTION: A structured comparison table of the four documentation types (tutorials, how-to guides, reference, explanation) showing their purposes, characteristics and distinctions using reStructuredText table formatting.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/map.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: restructuredtext
CODE:
```
.. list-table::
   :widths: 16 21 21 21 21
   :header-rows: 1
   :stub-columns: 1
   :class: wider

   * - \
     - :ref:`Tutorials <tutorials>`
     - :ref:`How-to guides <how-to>`
     - :ref:`Reference <reference>`
     - :ref:`Explanation <explanation>`
   * - what they do
     - introduce, educate, lead
     - guide
     - state, describe, inform
     - explain, clarify, discuss
   * - answers the question
     - "Can you teach me to...?"
     - "How do I...?"
     - "What is...?"
     - "Why...?"
   * - oriented to
     - learning
     - goals
     - information
     - understanding
   * - purpose
     - to provide a learning experience
     - to help achieve a particular goal
     - to describe the machinery
     - to illuminate a topic
   * - form
     - a lesson
     - a series of steps
     - dry description
     - discursive explanation
   * - analogy
     - teaching a child how to cook
     - a recipe in a cookery book
     - information on the back of a food packet
     - an article on culinary social history
```

TITLE: Tutorial Language Patterns in Technical Documentation
DESCRIPTION: Example phrases and language patterns to use when writing tutorials, demonstrating the proper tone and structure for guiding learners through technical content.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/tutorials.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: markdown
CODE:
```
We ...
    The first-person plural affirms the relationship between tutor and learner: you are not alone; we are in this together. 
In this tutorial, we will ...
    Describe what the learner will accomplish.
First, do x. Now, do y. Now that you have done y, do z.
    No room for ambiguity or doubt.
We must always do x before we do y because... (see Explanation for more details).
    Provide minimal explanation of actions in the most basic language possible. Link to more detailed explanation.
The output should look something like ...
    Give your learner clear expectations.
Notice that ... Remember that ... Let's check ...
    Give your learner plenty of clues to help confirm they are on the right track and orient themselves.
You have built a secure, three-layer hylomorphic stasis engine...
    Describe (and admire, in a mild way) what your learner has accomplished.
```

TITLE: Structuring Content for a How-to Landing Page
DESCRIPTION: An example of how to organize a How-to guides landing page with headings, introductory text, and categorized lists of guides to improve readability and provide context for users.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/complex-hierarchies.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
How to guides
=============

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.

Installation guides
-------------------

Pellentesque malesuada, ipsum ac mollis pellentesque, risus 
nunc ornare odio, et imperdiet dui mi et dui. Phasellus vel 
porta turpis. In feugiat ultricies ipsum.

* Local installation       |
* Docker                   |  links to
* Virtual machines         |  the guides
* Linux containers         |

Deployment and scaling
-----------------------

Morbi sed scelerisque ligula. In dictum lacus quis felis 
facilisisvulputate. Quisque lacinia condimentum ipsum 
laoreet tempus.

* Deploy an instance       |  links to
* Scale your application   |  the guides
```

TITLE: Describing Django's Default Logging Configuration in RestructuredText
DESCRIPTION: A sample reference documentation snippet showing how to document a technical feature (Django's default logging configuration) in a factual, information-oriented manner.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/reference.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: restructuredtext
CODE:
```
Django's default logging configuration inherits Python's defaults. It's available as ``django.utils.log.DEFAULT_LOGGING`` and defined in ``django/utils/log.py``
    State facts about the machinery and its behaviour.
Sub-commands are: a, b, c, d, e, f.
    List commands, options, operations, features, flags, limitations, error messages, etc.
You must use a. You must not apply b unless c. Never d.
    Provide warnings where appropriate.
```

TITLE: Organizing Documentation by User Context First
DESCRIPTION: A sample structure showing documentation organized primarily by user context (land, sea, air users) with Diátaxis elements as secondary categories within each context.
SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/complex-hierarchies.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```
tutorial
    for users on land
        [...]
    for users at sea
        [...]
    for users in the air
        [...]
[and then so on for how-to guides, reference and explanation]
```

TITLE: Organizing Documentation by Diátaxis Categories First

SOURCE: https://github.com/evildmp/diataxis-documentation-framework/blob/main/complex-hierarchies.rst#2025-04-22_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: text
CODE:
```

        [...]

        [...]
    reference
        [...]

        [...]
```
